title: Urgent warning issued as Australia Post scam targets vulnerable people to steal financial details
text:
An urgent warning has been issued over a convincing Australia Post scam that attempts to steal financial information from vulnerable people.

In a statement on Monday, Australia Post told customers to be cautious of a fraudulent text message in circulation.

The message says a parcel will not be delivered 'due to unverified shipping address' before prompting to click on a link below to amend the details.

In a statement on Monday, Australia Post (pictured) told customers to be cautious of a fraudulent text message in circulation

AusPost appears as the sender name - like any other legitimate message from the corporation - which means texts can sync into message threads already in the victim's phone.

The link leads to a fake website, with the company's logo, which asks for address verification and payment- which scammers then use to steal personal and financial information.

Australia Post reminded customers they will never ask for personal details online and to delete the message immediately.

'Please note that Australia Post will never email or text message you asking you to click on a link to print out a receipt/label for parcel collection/tracking or to access your package,' the statement read.

The link leads to a fake website (pictured), with the company's logo, which asks for address verification and payment- which scammers then use to steal personal and financial information

'Nor will Australia Post ask you to send an email containing any personal or financial information, including any form of ID, passwords, credit card details and account information.

'If you are in doubt about the authenticity of an email, text message or phone call, please delete immediately or hang up.

Identity theft has cost Australians almost $3million so far in 2019.

According to Scamwatch statistics, 918 reports were filed last month with fraudsters most frequently contacting victims via phone.
